message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury (landing on the anterior aspect of the knee) and the finding of posterior displacement of the left tibia when force is applied to the proximal tibia after flexing the knee suggest a Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury. An avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle supports this diagnosis as avulsion fractures are typically caused by the PCL being pulled off its attachment site on the condyle. The other options would have different mechanisms of injury and findings on physical examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury (slipping on the anterior aspect of the knee while attempting to kick the ball) and the physical examination findings (tenderness of the tibial tuberosity, limited range of motion, posterior displacement of the tibia upon force applied to the proximal tibia) suggest a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury. An avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle can also be associated with PCL injury. None of the other options match the mechanism of injury or physical examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury. The tenderness at the tibial tuberosity and the avulsion fracture on X-ray also support this diagnosis. The other options would likely present with different signs and symptoms, such as specific pain location or swelling.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including tenderness at the tibial tuberosity and displacement of the left tibia, suggest a posterior cruciate ligament injury. An avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle can also be seen with this injury. None of the other options present with symptoms consistent with the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The posterior displacement of the tibia indicates a posterior cruciate ligament injury, which can be caused by forceful landing on the anterior aspect of the knee. An avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle can also occur with this type of injury. The other options (medial meniscus injury, lateral meniscus injury, and medial collateral ligament injury) do not match the clinical findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and the findings on examination and imaging suggest a posterior cruciate ligament injury. The tibial displacement on flexion and posterior force applied to the proximal tibia are characteristic of a posterior cruciate ligament injury. An avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle is also commonly associated with this injury. Lateral and medial meniscus injuries typically present with joint line pain and swelling, while medial collateral ligament injuries present with pain and tenderness along the medial aspect of the knee.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injury occurred on the anterior aspect of the knee, and the tibial tuberosity shows tenderness to palpation. The left tibia is displaced posteriorly when force is applied to the proximal tibia after flexing the knee. These findings suggest a posterior cruciate ligament injury, which can cause displacement of the tibia posteriorly. The avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle is also consistent with this diagnosis. The other options, such as lateral or medial meniscus injury or medial collateral ligament injury, are less likely based on the given information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and the physical exam findings point towards a posterior cruciate ligament injury. The tenderness at the tibial tuberosity suggests an avulsion fracture, which is a common finding in PCL injuries. None of the other options are associated with these findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury with landing on the anterior aspect of the knee and displacement of the tibia posteriorly after flexing the knee suggests a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury. The avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle seen on x-ray also supports this diagnosis. The other options do not fit the mechanism of injury or exam findings as well.

The tenderness at the tibial tuberosity and the avulsion fracture are consistent with this diagnosis. None of the other options fit with the described mechanism of injury or clinical findings.
